thread.title: Ukraine Creditors Said to See Latest Debt Offer as Unacceptable
thread.title_full: Ukraine Creditors Said to See Latest Debt Offer as Unacceptable - Bloomberg Business

author: Natasha Doff
title: Ukraine Creditors Said to See Latest Debt Offer as Unacceptable
text:
The latest debt-restructuring offer from Ukraine’s government wouldn’t be acceptable to the nation’s bondholders, according to a person with knowledge of the negotiations.
A four-member creditor committee led by Franklin Templeton will fully review the proposal, submitted by Ukraine’s government on Tuesday, and aim to hold a call or meeting early next week to respond and discuss, the person said, asking not to be identified because the talks are private. The eastern European nation’s bonds fell for a third day.
The comments suggest the gap between the two sides remains wide as time runs out to reach a deal before the first bond matures on Sept. 23. Ukraine’s Finance Ministry said yesterday it wants bondholders represented at the “highest level” at a meeting in London on Thursday, calling this week “decisive” in reaching a $19 billion restructuring deal.
According to the person, holding a high-level direct meeting would be premature with just 48 hours notice given the geographically disperse nature of the committee’s membership. Franklin Templeton, Ukraine’s biggest bondholder, is based in San Mateo, California.
The other members of the group, which owns about $8.9 billion of Ukraine’s Eurobonds, are BTG Pactual Europe LLP, TCW Investment Management Co. and T. Rowe Price Associates Inc.
Ukraine’s finance ministry wasn’t immediately available for comment.
While the two sides have held direct meetings since signing confidentiality agreements last month, they still need to bridge their differences on the size of a principal reduction needed to meet the country’s restructuring targets under a $17.5 billion International Monetary Fund loan.
Ukraine asked creditors for a 40 percent principal reduction in June, a person with knowledge of the offer said at the time. Last week, the bondholder group proposed a 5 percent so-called haircut, the first time it’s accepted to take losses on its holdings, a separate person said.
